com.pb.sawdust.util.test

Class TestBase

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.util.test.TestBase

  • public abstract class TestBase
extends java.lang.Object
    The TestBase class is the base class from which all test classes should inherit from to enable the descriptive timing reporting provided by TestRunner. The test class merely needs to extend this class to enable the functionality, though some additional coding boilerplate is recommended:
    • A main(String[]) method should be included which looks like this: 
      
             public static void main(String ... args) {
                 TestBase.main();
             }
      This will enable the default behavior of running the tests in the class from its main method.
    • The org.junit.Assert class should be statically imported: 
      
             import static org.junit.Assert.*;
      This allows the use of assertEquals(...), assertArrayEquals(...), etc. directly rather than the clunkier Assert.assertEquals(...).

    When tests are run from main(String...), they will be multithreaded in the sense that the running of each test class instance (not each test) will be perfromed in parallel. The default maximum threadcount for this parallelization is set to the number of processors on the machine plus two, but can be overridden by specifying the threadcount as the first argument to the main method. Because of this default parallelization, great care must be taken to ensure that test classes are independant and threadsafe. As a specific example, static state should not be shared across test class instances, unless that static state is immutable. If this is not possible, then the tests must be run with the threadcount set to one.

    This class also offers some functionality which allows a test class to be applied more flexibly to different situations, such as dealing with multiple inheritence (from interfaces), shared test data, and test contexts. To deal with multiple inheritance, it is possible to specify "child" TestBase classes that should be run in addition to the current test class. This specification is performed through the getAdditionalTestClasses() method.

    Sharing test data across test classes is often desirable - this may be due to the need to minimize expensive test data construction or to pass along test-specific information to test classes returned by getAdditionalTestClasses(). Every test class instance can have test data associated with it through the addTestData methods. These provide a way of mapping a given (String) key to some test data specific to that class. This test data will be inherited by additional classes from getAdditionalTestClasses() which are run.

    Sometimes a single test class needs to be run multiple times for different contexts. For example, a class to test may be constructed in different ways, but the tests remain the same across all instances, so different context instances for each constructor (without repeating tests) would be useful. This class allows contexts to be attached to test classes through the addClassRunContext(Class, java.util.List) method. A context is defined as a map (String keys to object values) holding the context information. The getClassRunContext(Class) method can then be used for a specific test instance to determine which context it is running under. This framework is set up to be threadsafe and is preferable to static state variables (which will not work with the parallel test runs performed by this class).

    To help ensure that the contexts are being set correctly, the context information is printed out in the test summaries as they run. It is also possible to perform a "dry run" (see setDryRun(boolean)) where the test classes and contexts are listed, but no tests actually run, to quickly determine that the contexts are being established correctly.

    Due to the parallelization of the test running, it is essentially impossible to perform accurate test cleanup at a class level if multiple contexts or additional test classes have been specified. To assist with this cleanup, it is possible to "capture" which tests have been started between two code positions (specified by classStarted() and classFinished(Runnable), and then run some cleanup operations (defined by the runnable passed to the classFinished method) after all of these tests have finished. It is also possible, if desired, to register a cleanup method that will be performed after all tests have completed (registerCleanupMethod(Runnable)).

    Some reporting-level granularity is also provided through this class. Specifically, it is possible to add some additional test information which will be reported as each test is performed. Also, it is possible to set some test failure information (such as details about the failure beyond the assertion errors) which will be reported if the test fails.

    Additionally, this class contains a number of "(assert) almost equals" methods which can be used to compare float and double values and arrays. These methods determine whether values are within some error range of one another. Also, convenience methods dealing with creating temporary files a provided through this class. Finally, an instance of RandomDeluxe is available through this class (random).

      • setPrintoutExceptions

        public static void setPrintoutExceptions(boolean printoutExceptions)
        Specify whether exceptions caught during tests should be printed out explicitly by this class upon completion. The default behavior is to not print them out.
        Parameters:
        printoutExceptions - If true, exceptions will be printed out by this class, if false, they will not.

      • getAdditionalTestClasses

        protected java.util.Collection<java.lang.Class<? extends TestBase>> getAdditionalTestClasses()
        Get additional test classes to run tests on. This method can be overridden to capture multiple interface inheritance. By default, this returns an empty collection. Any test classes returned by this method will be run whenever this test class is run.
        Returns:
        additional test classes.

      • getCallingContextInstance

        protected TestBase getCallingContextInstance()
        Get an instance of the calling context class. That is, if this class was added to the test classes through a call to getAdditionalTestClasses(), then get an instance (freshly constructed) of the class whose getAdditionalTestClasses() method was called to get this class. This is slightly experimental and should only be used in a conservative manner.
        Returns:
        a calling context class instance.

      • getTestData

        protected java.lang.Object getTestData(java.lang.String key)
        Get the test data for a key associated with this instance's class. This method must be called from the same class instance as addTestData(String, Object) and thread to ensure correct context.
        Parameters:
        key - The data key.
        Returns:
        the data associated with key and this class.

        Parameters:
        testClass - The test class the key is associated with.
        key - The data key.
        Returns:
        the data associated with key and this class.

               java.lang.String key,
               java.lang.Object data)
        Add test data for a specified class. This data may be retrieved via getTestData(String). The test data will be associated with this class only in the calling thread, or for test classes called by this test class instance.
        Parameters:
        testClass - The test class to add the data for.
        key - The data key.
        data - The data value.

      • buildContext

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> buildContext(java.lang.String key,
                                                            java.lang.Object value)
        Convenience method to build a class run context from a single data key-value pair. This method can be used to initialize a class run context, which can then be modified further, if needed.
        Parameters:
        key - The data key.
        value - The data value.
        Returns:
        a map holding the key-value pair, suitable for use as a class run context.
        See Also:
        addClassRunContext(Class, java.util.List)

      • addClassRunContext

        public static void addClassRunContext(java.lang.Class<? extends TestBase> testClass,
                      java.util.List<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>> contextData)
        Add a series of class run contexts for a given test class. A class run context is a set of test data that can be used by a given class during a test (e.g. whether a certain algorithm is being tested in parallel or single-thread mode); it allows a single test class to be reused over a variety of circumstances. When this class's main method is called, a given test class will be run against each class run context specified. When a class's tests are run using a given context, then that context data is available through getTestData(String).

        For each class run context in the passed data, a new list of contexts combining it and the current contexts already existing for the test calss will be built (that is, they will be compounded/interleaved with each other). The run context is only valid for the specified class, and will not translate to subclasses (though subclasses may take advantage of the context by overriding getAdditionalTestClasses() and using getCallingContextInstance()).

        Parameters:
        testClass - The class to add the context for.
        contextData - The list of data, each defining a new context.

      • setAdditionalTestInformation

        protected void setAdditionalTestInformation(java.lang.String additionalInfo)
        Set additional test information for tests run from this thread. This information is reported in the detailed test reports created for this class. This information is only valid for tests run from the same thread that called this method.
        Parameters:
        additionalInfo - Additional test information to use with this test.

      • addAdditionalTestInformation

        protected void addAdditionalTestInformation(java.lang.String additionalInfo)
        Add additional test information for tests run from this thread. This method appends the information to the already existing additional information for the test reports created for this class. This information is only valid for tests run from the same thread that called this method.
        Parameters:
        additionalInfo - Additional test information to use with this test.

      • setDryRun

        public static void setDryRun(boolean dryRun)
        Sets whether tests will be a dry run or not. A dry run will print out all of the classes (and contexts) that would be tested, but no actual tests are run. The default is (of course) false.
        Parameters:
        dryRun - Whether tests should be run as a dry run or not.

        Returns:
        the list of test results.

        public static void printResultSummary(boolean printFailures)

        Parameters:
        printFailures - If true, then failure information will be printed, otherwise it will not be.

      • beforeClass

        public static void beforeClass()
        Perform some specific activity before the tests in the class are run. Currently just sets the additional test information to nothing (an empty string).

      • classStarted

        public static void classStarted()
        Indicate that a class has started calling tests. This method should be paired with a call to classFinished(Runnable) to setup class-level cleanup operations.

      • classFinished

        public static void classFinished(java.lang.Runnable finishMethod)
        Indicate that a class has finished calling tests, and what to do when those tests have finished. This method should be called after classStarted() for the test class.
        Parameters:
        finishMethod - The cleanup actions to perform after all the tests captured by this class have finished.

      • registerCleanupMethod

        public static void registerCleanupMethod(java.lang.Runnable runnable)
        Register a cleanup method. This method will be run after all tests have finished (not just the ones from the class(es) that this method was called from.
        Parameters:
        runnable - The method (as a runnable) which will be run to cleanup after all tests have finished.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String... args)
        Main method which will run any tests contained in the calling class (does not have to (nor should it) be TestBase). These are multi-threaded by default, using a threadcount equal to the number of processors plus two. Alternatively, the user may override this default by specifying the first argument (as a positive integer) which will be used as the threadcount.
        Parameters:
        args - If args.length > 0 then the first argument will be used as the threadcount for the tests. This argument is only relevant if this is the first time this method is called in the test suite chain.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if args.length > 0 and either args[0] cannot be parsed into an integer or args[0] < 1.

      • getTemporaryFile

        public static java.io.File getTemporaryFile(java.lang.Class testClass,
                            java.lang.String fileName)
        Get a temporary file location for a test class. The temporary location will be the same as the (compiled) class' classpath location. That is, if the class is packageA.packageB.Clazz, then the temporary file path will be the location of the packaeA directory, or the location of the jar file the class is in (or wherever else the class's "root" is located). This file will be set to be deleted when the jvm exits.
        Parameters:
        testClass - The test class to generate the temporary file for; the classpath root for this class will be used for the temp file location.
        fileName - The temporary file name.
        Returns:
        a File object pointing to the temporary file.

      • getTemporaryFile

        public static java.io.File getTemporaryFile(java.lang.Class testClass,
                            java.io.File subDir,
                            java.lang.String fileName)
        Get a temporary file location for a test class. The temporary location will be the same as the (compiled) class' classpath location, plus the specified sub-directories. That is, if the class is packageA.packageB.Clazz, then the temporary file path will be the location of the packaeA directory, or the location of the jar file the class is in (or wherever else the class's "root" is located), plus the sub-directories. If they do not exist, the sub-directries will be created. This file and its subdirectories will be set to be deleted when the jvm exits.
        Parameters:
        testClass - The test class to generate the temporary file for; the classpath root for this class will be used for the temp file location.
        fileName - The temporary file name.
        subDir - The sub-directories to place the file in.
        Returns:
        a File object pointing to the temporary file.

      • getTemporaryFileDirectory

        public static java.io.File getTemporaryFileDirectory(java.lang.Class testClass,
                                     java.io.File subDir)
        Get a temporary directory location for a test class. The temporary location will be the same as the (compiled) class's classpath location, plus the specified sub-directories. That is, if the class is packageA.packageB.Clazz, then the temporary path will be the location of the packaeA directory, or the location of the jar file the class is in (or wherever else the class's "root" is located), plus the sub-directories. If they do not exist, the sub-directries will be created. The sub-directories will be set to be deleted when the jvm exits.
        Parameters:
        testClass - The test class to locate the temporary directory for; the classpath root for this class will be used for the temp directory.
        subDir - The sub-directories.
        Returns:
        a File object pointing to the temporary directory location.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - if the directories specified by subDir could not (if necessary) be created.

      • getTemporaryFileDirectory

        public static java.io.File getTemporaryFileDirectory(java.lang.Class testClass)
        Get a temporary directory location for a test class. The temporary location will be the same as the (compiled) class's classpath location. That is, if the class is packageA.packageB.Clazz, then the temporary path will be the location of the packaeA directory, or the location of the jar file the class is in (or wherever else the class's "root" is located).
        Parameters:
        testClass - The test class to locate the temporary directory for; the classpath root for this class will be used for the temp directory.
        Returns:
        a File object pointing to the temporary directory location.

      • assertAlmostEquals

        public void assertAlmostEquals(float expected,
                      float actual,
                      float delta,
                      float epsilon)
        Assert that two float values are almost equal. Two non-zero values, v1 and v2, are almost equal if ||v1 - v2|/v1| < delta. If either of the values are zero, then the values are almost equal if the absolute value of the other value is less than epsilon.
        Parameters:
        expected - The expected value.
        actual - The actual value.
        delta - The delta to use in the almost equals calculation.
        epsilon - The epsilon to use in the almost equal calculation.

      • assertAlmostEquals

        public void assertAlmostEquals(float expected,
                      float actual)
        Assert that two float values are almost equal within the default delta MathUtil.DEFAULT_ALMOST_EQUALS_DELTA and the default epsilon MathUtil.DEFAULT_EQUALS_ZERO_EPSILON. Two non-zero values, v1 and v2, are almost equal if ||v1 - v2|/v1| < delta. If either of the values are zero, then the values are almost equal if the absolute value of the other value is less than epsilon.
        Parameters:
        expected - The expected value.
        actual - The actual value.

      • assertAlmostEquals

        public void assertAlmostEquals(java.lang.Object expected,
                      java.lang.Object actual,
                      double delta,
                      double epsilon)
        Assert that two values are almost equal. Two non-zero values, v1 and v2, are almost equal if ||v1 - v2|/v1| < delta. If either of the values are zero, then the values are almost equal if the absolute value of the other value is less than epsilon. If the expected and actual values are not both Double or both Float instances, then equality is determined using expected.equals(actual).
        Parameters:
        expected - The expected value.
        actual - The actual value.
        delta - The delta to use in the almost equals calculation.
        epsilon - The epsilon to use in the almost equal calculation.

      • assertAlmostEquals

        public void assertAlmostEquals(java.lang.Object expected,
                      java.lang.Object actual)
        Assert if two values are almost equal within the default delta MathUtil.DEFAULT_ALMOST_EQUALS_DELTA and the defaul epsilon MathUtil.DEFAULT_EQUALS_ZERO_EPSILON. Two non-zero values, v1 and v2, are almost equal if ||v1 - v2|/v1| < delta. If either of the values are zero, then the values are almost equal if the absolute value of the other value is less than epsilon. If the expected and actual values are not both Double or both Float instances, then equality is determined using expected.equals(actual).
        Parameters:
        expected - The expected value.
        actual - The actual value.

      • assertArrayAlmostEquals

        public void assertArrayAlmostEquals(float[] expected,
                           float[] actual,
                           double delta,
                           double epsilon)
        Assert two float arrays are almost equal. The arrays are almost equal if they each have the same length and each corresponding element, e1 and e2, are almost equal (see MathUtil.almostEquals(float, float, float, float))
        Parameters:
        expected - The expected value.
        actual - The actual value.
        delta - The delta to use in the almost equals calculation.
        epsilon - The epsilon to use in the almost equal calculation.

      • assertArrayAlmostEquals

        public void assertArrayAlmostEquals(float[] expected,
                           float[] actual)
        Assert two float arrays are almost equal within the default delta MathUtil.DEFAULT_ALMOST_EQUALS_DELTA and default epsilon MathUtil.DEFAULT_EQUALS_ZERO_EPSILON. The arrays are almost equal if they each have the same length and each corresponding element, e1 and e2, are almost equal: (see MathUtil.almostEquals(float, float))
        Parameters:
        expected - The expected value.
        actual - The actual value.

      • assertArrayAlmostEquals

        public void assertArrayAlmostEquals(double[] expected,
                           double[] actual,
                           double delta,
                           double epsilon)
        Assert two float double are almost equal. The arrays are almost equal if they each have the same length and each corresponding element, e1 and e2, are almost equal (see MathUtil.almostEquals(double, double, double, double))

        actual - The actual value.
        delta - The delta to use in the almost equals calculation.
        epsilon - The epsilon to use in the almost equal calculation.

      • assertArrayAlmostEquals

        public void assertArrayAlmostEquals(double[] expected,
                           double[] actual)
        Assert two double arrays are almost equal within the default delta MathUtil.DEFAULT_ALMOST_EQUALS_DELTA and default epsilon MathUtil.DEFAULT_EQUALS_ZERO_EPSILON. The arrays are almost equal if they each have the same length and each corresponding element, e1 and e2, are almost equal: see MathUtil.almostEquals(double, double).
        Parameters:
        expected - The expected value.
        actual - The actual value.

      • assertArrayAlmostEquals

        public void assertArrayAlmostEquals(java.lang.Object expected,
                           java.lang.Object actual,
                           double delta,
                           double epsilon)
        Assert two object arrays are almost equal. The arrays are almost equal if they each have the same length and each corresponding element, e1 and e2, are almost equal: see MathUtil.almostEquals(java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object, double, double). If two corresponding elements are not both Float or both Double instances then org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(expected,actual) is called to determine equality.
        Parameters:
        expected - The expected value.
        actual - The actual value.
        delta - The delta to use in the almost equals calculation.
        epsilon - The epsilon to use in the almost equal calculation.

      • assertArrayAlmostEquals

        public void assertArrayAlmostEquals(java.lang.Object expected,
                           java.lang.Object actual)
        Assert two object arrays are almost equal within the default delta MathUtil.DEFAULT_ALMOST_EQUALS_DELTA and the default epsilon MathUtil.DEFAULT_EQUALS_ZERO_EPSILON. The arrays are almost equal if they each have the same length and each corresponding element, e1 and e2, are almost equal: see MathUtil.almostEquals(java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object). If two corresponding elements are not both Float or both Double instances then org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(expected,actual) is called to determine equality.
        Parameters:
        expected - The expected value.
        actual - The actual value.
